Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI proposes to continue his research in geometric structures on low-dimensional manifolds, deformations of discrete groups, and moduli of surface group representations. One problem involves completing the classification problem for proper affine actions, a basic problem in geometry whose history stretches back to the classification of Euclidean crystallographic groups in the early 20th century. In the last 25 years, the classification in 3 dimensions has been reduced to a problem in 2-dimensional hyperbolic geometry. Another side of this general problem stems from the observation that deformation spaces of geometric structures are themselves locally modeled on representation spaces of fundamental groups. This naturally leads to dynamical questions on actions of mapping class groups. Moduli spaces of surface group representations support invariant Poisson structures, as well as finer structures depending on a conformal structure. The dependence of these as the Riemann surface varies over Teichmueller space is crucial to understanding dynamics of surface group representations.

This research focuses on the relation between topology and geometry. While topology concerns the loose qualitative organization of patterns of points, geometry concerns quantitative measurements such as distance, angle and area. These two viewpoints are compared through symmetries, leading to algebraic calculations involving groups. The Experimental Geometry Lab has been a center for the PI and his students and collaborators (at all levels) to develop tools for these calculations and visualization. Many of the above projects have an experimental component and the PI will continue to work with students (from high school to postdocs) to develop user-friendly software to assist in their investigation and dissemination.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While geometry refers to measurements and quantitative relationships between objects such as "points",  "lines", "curves" and "surfaces", the subject of topology deals with the more flexible qualitative properties of a loosely organized collection of points. An example of topology is our usual abstract conception of Earth as  a 2-dimensional sphere. As such it is topologically equivalent to a cube or a more general convex polyhedron. However, a basic theorem in the subject is that this topology does not support an intrinsic Euclidean geometry: since there is no metrically accurate world atlas, covering a sphere with local coordinates in which the measurements agree with that of Euclidean space is impossible. However, by enlarging Euclidean geometry to be either projective (where distances may be distorted but lines and points remain) or conformal (where notions of angle are preserved), this topology does support these larger geometries. Similarly, the torus (the topology of the surface of a bagel or inner-tube) does support Euclidean geometry. Furthermore the different Euclidean geometries on a torus form a fundamental mathematical object (a moduli space) with a rich and interesting geometry of its own.

The purpose of this project is to classify the different geometric structures on a fixed topology and analyze the geometry of the corresponding moduli space. These structures arise in many contexts, including computer sicence and  mathematical physics. The grant supported many graduate students, postdocs and undergraduates working the University of Maryland's Experimental Geometry Lab. The spaces of interest  can profitably be analyzed using computer visualization. We have found that visualization projects are an excellent way to bring students into mathematics, and software development is an exciting way for students to make significant contributions to research in this subject. Several of the computer visualizations have appeared in the PI's publications and presentations at international conferences and workshops. Two of the attached drawings were the goal of a student project in our lab, involving symmetrical patterns in non-Euclidean hyperbolic geometry.

One research project, which the PI began as a graduate student in the 1970's, particulary flourished during the award period. This is the classification of complete affine 3-dimensional manifolds. These are general crystals whose symmetries preserve a Lorentzian structure --- which is the relativistic geometry of a vacuum with 2 space dimensions (and 1 time dimension). Crystallographic groups in Euclidean geometry were classified in the 1910's but the more general structures are only beginning to be understood. The most interesting examples were discovered by Margulis around 1980, and were quite unexpected at the time. The PI has led an intensive research project and these manifolds are now well understood. In particular we have discovered intimate relationships between these objects and structures from  diverse other areas of mathematics, such as non-Euclidean geometry, group theory, dynamical systems and arithmetic. An attached graphic depicts a 2-dimensional cross-section (in the 2 space dimensions) of a tiling of 3-space arising from a Margulis spacetime.
